elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig001">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Section of the structure of Ni(II) gallate dihydrate in a plane containing the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis. Chains of NiO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedra are connected by roughly planar gallate groups. The structures of the other gallates are analogous.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr002"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  Section of the structure of Ni(II) gallate dihydrate in a plane containing the c axis. Chains of NiO6 octahedra are connected by roughly planar gallate groups. The structures of the other gallates are analogous.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig002">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">View down the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis of the gallate structure. Unbound water molecules occupy trigonal channels between chains of <mml:math altimg="si12.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>
<mml:msub>
<mml:mi mathvariant="normal">O</mml:mi>
<mml:mn>6</mml:mn>
</mml:msub>
</mml:math> octahedra.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr003"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  View down the c axis of the gallate structure. Unbound water molecules occupy trigonal channels between chains of  M  O 6   octahedra.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig003">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Inverse magnetic susceptibility of the metal gallates at 1000 Oe, field cooled. Minima are at 19 K for Ni(II) and at 43 K for Co(II).</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr004"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  Inverse magnetic susceptibility of the metal gallates at 1000 Oe, field cooled. Minima are at 19 K for Ni(II) and at 43 K for Co(II).

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

We report the synthesis, crystal structures, magnetic properties, and thermal behavior of a family of isostructural transition metal gallate dihydrates containing infinite chains of trans-corner-sharing  M  O 6   octahedra. The gallates crystallize in the enantiomorphic space groups  P  3 1  21  and  P  3 2  21 , chirality being imparted by helical motifs in the structure. Ni(C7O5H4)⋅2H2O:  a = 8.824 ( 2 )   Å ,  c = 10.644 ( 2 )   Å ; Mn(C7O5H4)⋅2H2O:  a = 9.063 ( 2 )   Å ,  c = 10.947 ( 2 )   Å ; Co(C7O5H4)⋅2H2O:  a = 8.910 ( 2 )   Å ,  c = 10.887 ( 2 )   Å . The Co(II) and Ni(II) gallates exhibit antiferromagnetic behavior, with   T N  = 43  and 19 K, respectively, while Mn(II) gallate is paramagnetic down to 5 K. High-temperature X-ray powder diffraction indicates that crystallinity is lost near 200°C in all of the compounds. Decarboxylation of the gallate moieties is believed to facilitate this thermal decomposition.

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract



Introduction

Zeolites, AlPOs, porous transition metal phosphates, and other low-density inorganic solids have been widely investigated over the last 20 years . In 1990, Hoskins and Robson  reported some of the first compounds of this type to utilize organic molecules as major structural elements, directly bonded to metal cations. Since then, this area has emerged as a major growth area .

elements.content:
<ce:figure>
<ce:link locator="gr001"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:para view="all">Metal-organic frameworks comprise two broad classes: (i) coordination polymers, in which isolated metal ions or clusters are linked through organic groups to form infinite arrays in one, two, or three dimensions, and (ii) systems in which there is extended connectivity of the inorganic components, which may be further cross-linked or decorated by organic groups. In this second class, the materials can be thought of as hybrid metal oxides if the organic groups are coordinated to the metals via oxygen atoms. Systems with 1-D, 2-D and 3-D connectivity have been observed . Typically, both types of frameworks have been synthesized under mild hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions (60–250 °C).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks comprise two broad classes: (i) coordination polymers, in which isolated metal ions or clusters are linked through organic groups to form infinite arrays in one, two, or three dimensions, and (ii) systems in which there is extended connectivity of the inorganic components, which may be further cross-linked or decorated by organic groups. In this second class, the materials can be thought of as hybrid metal oxides if the organic groups are coordinated to the metals via oxygen atoms. Systems with 1-D, 2-D and 3-D connectivity have been observed . Typically, both types of frameworks have been synthesized under mild hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions (60-250°C).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Gallic acid (3,4,5-trihydroxybenzoic acid, C<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>) is a suitable candidate for forming hybrid frameworks because it has five available oxygen atoms, distributed on opposite sides of the molecule, with relatively large gaps between the phenolic oxygens that are able to chelate to metal ions. Iron gallate has been known since antiquity , and has been used as an ink and a dye on account of its strong absorption in the visible region. Close inspection of its crystal structure, which was reported in 1991 , reveals that it is a classic example of a 1-D hybrid metal oxide, containing infinite chains of <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-corner-sharing FeO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedra (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig001"></ce:float-anchor>). The chains are cross-linked by the gallate to form channels that contain uncoordinated water (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig002"></ce:float-anchor>). Since the trivalent state of the iron was verified using Mössbauer and XANES spectroscopies, the formula can be represented as Fe(C<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)⋅2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, though the location of the proton that is required for charge balance remains unclear. In the present work, we have shown that the same structure type can be obtained with the divalent ions, <ce:italic>M</ce:italic>(C<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)⋅2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, <mml:math altimg="si11.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>
<mml:mo>=</mml:mo>
<mml:mi mathvariant="normal">Mn</mml:mi>
<mml:mo stretchy="false">(</mml:mo>
<mml:mi mathvariant="normal">II</mml:mi>
<mml:mo stretchy="false">)</mml:mo>
</mml:math>, Co(II) and Ni(II). We have studied the magnetic properties of these materials and compared them with those of the Fe(III) compound.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Gallic acid (3,4,5-trihydroxybenzoic acid, C7O5H6) is a suitable candidate for forming hybrid frameworks because it has five available oxygen atoms, distributed on opposite sides of the molecule, with relatively large gaps between the phenolic oxygens that are able to chelate to metal ions. Iron gallate has been known since antiquity , and has been used as an ink and a dye on account of its strong absorption in the visible region. Close inspection of its crystal structure, which was reported in 1991 , reveals that it is a classic example of a 1-D hybrid metal oxide, containing infinite chains of trans-corner-sharing FeO6 octahedra ( ). The chains are cross-linked by the gallate to form channels that contain uncoordinated water ( ). Since the trivalent state of the iron was verified using Mössbauer and XANES spectroscopies, the formula can be represented as Fe(C7O5H3)⋅2H2O, though the location of the proton that is required for charge balance remains unclear. In the present work, we have shown that the same structure type can be obtained with the divalent ions, M(C7O5H4)⋅2H2O,  M = Mn ( II ) , Co(II) and Ni(II). We have studied the magnetic properties of these materials and compared them with those of the Fe(III) compound.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental details

Synthesis

Wunderlich et al. originally grew crystals of iron gallate at room temperature using the silica gel method . By contrast, we have used hydrothermal methods to synthesize the Fe(III), Mn(II), Co(II) and Ni(II) compounds. Bluish-black rod-shaped crystals ( 0.3 × 0.1 × 0.1   mm ) of Fe(III) gallate were synthesized by combining 1 mmol (199 mg) FeCl2⋅4H2O (Aldrich, 99%) and 1 mmol (188 mg) gallic acid monohydrate (Alfa Aesar, 98+%) with 10 mL of 0.05M KOH. This mixture was sealed in a teflon-lined Parr acid digestion bomb and heated at 100°C under autogenous pressure for 72 h. The reaction vessel was cooled at room temperature, and the product washed with deionized water and vacuum-filtered. Phase-pure powders were produced by combining 50 mg NaSO3 (Fisher, ACS grade) with the FeCl2⋅4H2O and gallic acid in 10 mL of 0.06 M KOH, and heating at 125°C under autogenous pressure for 48 h. Medium-brown rod-shaped crystals ( 0.5 × 0.1 × 0.1   mm ) of Mn(II) gallate were synthesized in a similar manner but using 1 mmol (169 mg) MnSO4⋅H2O (ACROS, 99%). This mixture was heated at 110°C for 67 h. A phase-pure powder was produced similarly, but using 0.1 M KOH instead of 0.06 M. A dark brown block-shaped crystal ( 0.07 × 0.1 × 0.1   mm ) of Ni(II) gallate was isolated from a phase-pure powder that had been prepared by heating 1 mmol (249 mg) Ni(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O (Aldrich, 98%) and 1 mmol gallic acid monohydrate in 10 mL deionized water at 100°C for 93 h. Larger block crystals were later grown using only 150 mg Ni(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O and heating at 110°C for 46 h, but these were not necessary for structure solution. No single crystals of Co(II) gallate were obtained, but phase-pure powders were made using 1 mmol (238 mg) CoCl2⋅6H2O (Aldrich, 98%) and 1 mmol gallic acid monohydrate in 10 mL of 0.04 M KOH, heated to 100°C for 48 h. Later, some microcrystals were grown using cobalt (II) acetate and acetylacetonate in deionized water, at  1 : 1  and  1 : 2  stoichiometries with the gallic acid, and at lower overall concentrations than before. Phase-pure powders with microcrystals were grown between 75-150°C.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Elemental analysis (C, H, N) of the powders used for characterization indicated 31.28% C and 3.03% H for Ni (II) gallate (expected 31.98% and 3.07%), 29.95% C and 2.70% H for Fe (III) gallate (expected 32.46% and 2.73%), 28.43% C and 2.82% H for Mn (II) gallate (expected 32.45% and 3.12%), and 30.63% C and 2.92% H for Co (II) gallate (expected 31.96% and 3.07%). Analysis was performed by the Analytical Laboratory at the UCSB Marine Sciences Institute.</ce:para>

elements.clean_text: Synthesis was effective when the mixed solutions had pH's in the range of 3.5-5, suggesting that the degree of deprotonation of the gallic acid before heating plays a substantial role in crystal nucleation and growth kinetics. The  p  K a  's of the four acidic protons in gallic acid have been reported as 4.4, 8.7, 11.4, and 13.0 , the most acidic proton being that of the carboxylic acid group. In solution, the second deprotonation of gallic acid would be expected on the para phenol, which leaves the dianion stabilized by two internal hydrogen bonds. This will be reflected later in the structure of the frameworks (see below).

elements.clean_text:
Structure determinations

Single crystals of Fe(III), Mn(II), and Ni(II) gallates were selected under a polarizing microscope and glued to a glass fiber. Intensity data were collected at room temperature on a Siemens SMART CCD diffractometer ( Mo   K α   radiation,  λ = 0.71073   Å ). Structures were solved using direct methods and difference Fourier synthesis, and refined against    | F |  2   using the SHELXTL software package . Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Absorption corrections were made using SADABS . Hydrogen atoms were found in the Fourier map and refined isotropically. Extinction coefficients refined to within three e.s.d.'s of zero, and were thus removed from the refinement. See   for Ni(II) gallate, and   for Mn(II) gallate. Crystal data for Fe(III) gallate is not reported because it was effectively identical to data from Wunderlich et al.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Some hydrogens were restrained to reasonable positions. For Mn(II) gallate, the water O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H bond lengths were restrained to 0.8 Å, and the water H<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H distance restrained to 1.3 Å. For Ni(II) gallate, the water O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H bond lengths were restrained to 0.85 Å, the isotropic thermal parameters of the water hydrogens were set equal, and antibumping constraints were imposed between the phenylic and phenolic hydrogens and their respective mother atoms.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Some hydrogens were restrained to reasonable positions. For Mn(II) gallate, the water OH bond lengths were restrained to 0.8 Å, and the water HH distance restrained to 1.3 Å. For Ni(II) gallate, the water OH bond lengths were restrained to 0.85 Å, the isotropic thermal parameters of the water hydrogens were set equal, and antibumping constraints were imposed between the phenylic and phenolic hydrogens and their respective mother atoms.

elements.clean_text:
Other measurements

TGA/DTA analysis was performed in air on a Mettler 851e TG/sDTA up to 600°C. Temperatures were ramped at 5°C/min. Powder diffractometry was performed on a Phillips X'Pert diffractometer equipped with  Cu   K α   radiation ( λ = 1.5418   Å ) and a Phillips X'Celerator array detector. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on a Quantum Design MPMS 5XL SQUID magnetometer. Zero-field-cooled and field-cooled susceptibility measurements were performed from 5-400 K at a field strength of 1000 Oe, with a temperature ramp rate of 5°C/min. High-temperature powder X-ray diffractometry was performed using  Cu   K α   radiation ( λ = 1.5418   Å ) under static air in a Bruker D8 Advance Diffractometer outfitted with a Braun Position Sensitive Detector and an Anton Paar HTK 16 high temperature stage. Patterns were scanned at 50°C intervals from 50 to 500°C, with temperature ramps of 30°C/min between scans, followed by 2 minute pauses to thermally equilibrate.

<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The Fe(III), Mn(II), and Ni(II) gallates are essentially isostructural, though the structures with the divalent cations clearly require an additional proton for charge balance. They crystallize in the enantiomeric space groups <mml:math altimg="si42.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mi>P</mml:mi>

<mml:mn>3</mml:mn>

</mml:msub>
<mml:mn>21</mml:mn>
</mml:math> or <mml:math altimg="si43.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mi>P</mml:mi>
<mml:msub>
<mml:mn>3</mml:mn>
<mml:mn>1</mml:mn>
</mml:msub>
<mml:mn>21</mml:mn>
</mml:math>, and consist of hexagonal arrays of slightly twisting chains of <mml:math altimg="si44.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>
<mml:msub>
<mml:mi mathvariant="normal">O</mml:mi>
<mml:mn>6</mml:mn>
</mml:msub>
</mml:math> octahedra (). Lying roughly parallel to these chains are the largely planar organic groups, which form a scaffolding that bridges the chains to each other (). The geometry allows for a unique situation in which achiral organic groups assume positions around screw axes to form either one of two enantiomeric chiral frameworks. The coordination spheres of the metal cations are filled completely by oxygen atoms from the gallate groups, with no direct coordination of water. Free water molecules are found within the channels, and are both donors and acceptors of hydrogen-bonds with the gallate oxygens (O2 to O6 (water), and O6 to O5). Each asymmetric unit contains half of the symmetrical gallate anion, half of the metal cation site, which lies on a twofold rotation axis, and one channel water molecule, making these compounds dihydrates. Fe(III) gallate was originally reported as a protonated monohydrate, i.e., Fe(C<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)⋅H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, but it is actually a dihydrate. By analogy to our Mn(II) and Ni(II) phases, the proton probably resides on one of the gallate phenolic oxygens rather than on the water molecule. In other respects, our structure for the Fe(III) gallate concurs with that reported previously.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

The Fe(III), Mn(II), and Ni(II) gallates are essentially isostructural, though the structures with the divalent cations clearly require an additional proton for charge balance. They crystallize in the enantiomeric space groups  P  3 2  21  or  P  3 1  21 , and consist of hexagonal arrays of slightly twisting chains of  M  O 6   octahedra (). Lying roughly parallel to these chains are the largely planar organic groups, which form a scaffolding that bridges the chains to each other (). The geometry allows for a unique situation in which achiral organic groups assume positions around screw axes to form either one of two enantiomeric chiral frameworks. The coordination spheres of the metal cations are filled completely by oxygen atoms from the gallate groups, with no direct coordination of water. Free water molecules are found within the channels, and are both donors and acceptors of hydrogen-bonds with the gallate oxygens (O2 to O6 (water), and O6 to O5). Each asymmetric unit contains half of the symmetrical gallate anion, half of the metal cation site, which lies on a twofold rotation axis, and one channel water molecule, making these compounds dihydrates. Fe(III) gallate was originally reported as a protonated monohydrate, i.e., Fe(C7O5H2)⋅H3O+, but it is actually a dihydrate. By analogy to our Mn(II) and Ni(II) phases, the proton probably resides on one of the gallate phenolic oxygens rather than on the water molecule. In other respects, our structure for the Fe(III) gallate concurs with that reported previously.

elements.clean_text: There are a few geometrical differences between the structures of the Fe(III), Mn(II) and Ni(II) gallates. Fe (III) gallate has a  c / a  ratio of 1.254, while the Mn(II) and Ni(II) compounds have  c / a  ratios of 1.208 and 1.206, respectively. These differing ratios manifest themselves in the more sharply tilted chains of octahedra with the divalent cations: the M O M is 137.4° for Fe(III), but only 124.5° and 131.3°, respectively for Mn(II) and Ni(II) gallates. In addition, the torsion angle about the CC single bond is higher for Mn(II) and Ni(II) (35.8° and 33.1°, respectively) versus 29.1° for Fe(III) gallate. On the basis of its intermediate  c / a  ratio of 1.222, the M O M angle in the Co(II) compound should be between 130-135°. The degree of tilting in these compounds will have an influence on their magnetic properties, discussed below.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">One of the remarkable features of the metal gallate structure is that it can clearly accommodate both divalent and trivalent cations. We have examined how the structure is able to do this while maintaining charge balance. In future work we shall examine this question by neutron diffraction, but our current thinking is that the two protons in the divalent structure are located on the two <ce:italic>meta</ce:italic> phenol oxygens of the gallate groups. These two oxygens would be easier to protonate than the <ce:italic>para</ce:italic> phenol, both because they are less acidic and because the <ce:italic>para</ce:italic> phenol is already <mml:math altimg="si49.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:msub>
<mml:mi>μ</mml:mi>
<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>
</mml:msub>
</mml:math>-coordinated. In the case of the Fe(III) compound, we believe that one half of these phenolic oxygens are protonated, rather than the channel water molecules.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: One of the remarkable features of the metal gallate structure is that it can clearly accommodate both divalent and trivalent cations. We have examined how the structure is able to do this while maintaining charge balance. In future work we shall examine this question by neutron diffraction, but our current thinking is that the two protons in the divalent structure are located on the two meta phenol oxygens of the gallate groups. These two oxygens would be easier to protonate than the para phenol, both because they are less acidic and because the para phenol is already   μ 2  -coordinated. In the case of the Fe(III) compound, we believe that one half of these phenolic oxygens are protonated, rather than the channel water molecules.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The gallates' virtually identical structures, ability to accept multiple cation valences, ability to form over a wide temperature range, and highly rigid organic groups, together suggest that there may be little structural diversity among metal gallates, compared to other systems such as the cobalt succinates . There may in fact be only one thermodynamically accessible crystal structure for metal gallates, even over a wide range of cation radii, because of the inflexibility of the gallate groups. Future studies with main group metals and lanthanides may confirm or disprove this.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The gallates' virtually identical structures, ability to accept multiple cation valences, ability to form over a wide temperature range, and highly rigid organic groups, together suggest that there may be little structural diversity among metal gallates, compared to other systems such as the cobalt succinates . There may in fact be only one thermodynamically accessible crystal structure for metal gallates, even over a wide range of cation radii, because of the inflexibility of the gallate groups. Future studies with main group metals and lanthanides may confirm or disprove this.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Thermogravimetric curves for the gallates showed similar weight losses, but in different temperature ranges. Fe(III) gallate had the earliest weight loss, losing 68.0% of its total weight, mostly between 250 and 320 °C. Mn(II) gallate lost 70.3%, but more gradually, with the major loss between 310 and 380 °C. Ni(II) gallate similarly lost 72.5%, mostly between 320 and 390 °C. Co(II) gallate had the latest and most gradual weight loss, losing 69.4% of its total weight, with the major loss between 310 and 415 °C. Theoretical weight losses accompanying decomposition to binary oxides of the same valence are 69.2% for Fe(III), 72.6% for Mn(II), 71.6% for Ni(II), and 71.5% for Co(II). The formation of Fe<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, MnO, NiO, and CoO is confirmed by peaks that appear in the high-temperature X-ray powder diffraction patterns above the temperatures of final mass loss. Very slight weight gains in Mn(II) and Co(II) gallates in the highest temperature range (above 450 °C) presumably correspond to further oxidation of MnO and CoO to Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, respectively. High-temperature powder diffraction indicates that crystallinity is lost much earlier than the major TGA weight losses: below 150 °C for Fe(III) gallate, around 200 °C for Co(II) and Mn(II) gallate, and slightly above 200 °C for Ni (II) gallate.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric curves for the gallates showed similar weight losses, but in different temperature ranges. Fe(III) gallate had the earliest weight loss, losing 68.0% of its total weight, mostly between 250 and 320°C. Mn(II) gallate lost 70.3%, but more gradually, with the major loss between 310 and 380°C. Ni(II) gallate similarly lost 72.5%, mostly between 320 and 390°C. Co(II) gallate had the latest and most gradual weight loss, losing 69.4% of its total weight, with the major loss between 310 and 415°C. Theoretical weight losses accompanying decomposition to binary oxides of the same valence are 69.2% for Fe(III), 72.6% for Mn(II), 71.6% for Ni(II), and 71.5% for Co(II). The formation of Fe2O3, MnO, NiO, and CoO is confirmed by peaks that appear in the high-temperature X-ray powder diffraction patterns above the temperatures of final mass loss. Very slight weight gains in Mn(II) and Co(II) gallates in the highest temperature range (above 450°C) presumably correspond to further oxidation of MnO and CoO to Mn2O3 and Co3O4, respectively. High-temperature powder diffraction indicates that crystallinity is lost much earlier than the major TGA weight losses: below 150°C for Fe(III) gallate, around 200°C for Co(II) and Mn(II) gallate, and slightly above 200°C for Ni (II) gallate.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Large exotherms in the DTA curves coincided with these mass losses. An additional sharp exotherm was seen at 150 °C for Fe(III) gallate, and a somewhat smaller additional exotherm was seen at 200 °C for Ni(II) gallate. Conversely, Mn(II) gallate showed a very minor endotherm at 170 °C. Co(II) gallate appears to exhibit both a small endotherm near 160 °C and a small exotherm near 200 °C. Gallic acid is known to decarboxylate to pyrogallol (1,2,3-benzenetriol) at 175 °C , so it is likely that the decomposition of the gallates to binary oxides is prompted by this decarboxylation, which destroys the framework structures. Theoretical and experimental studies by Li and Brill  indicate that <ce:italic>meta</ce:italic> hydroxyl groups tend to stabilize benzoic acids against decarboxylation, whereas <ce:italic>para</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>ortho</ce:italic> hydroxyls tend to destabilize them.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Large exotherms in the DTA curves coincided with these mass losses. An additional sharp exotherm was seen at 150°C for Fe(III) gallate, and a somewhat smaller additional exotherm was seen at 200°C for Ni(II) gallate. Conversely, Mn(II) gallate showed a very minor endotherm at 170°C. Co(II) gallate appears to exhibit both a small endotherm near 160°C and a small exotherm near 200°C. Gallic acid is known to decarboxylate to pyrogallol (1,2,3-benzenetriol) at 175°C , so it is likely that the decomposition of the gallates to binary oxides is prompted by this decarboxylation, which destroys the framework structures. Theoretical and experimental studies by Li and Brill  indicate that meta hydroxyl groups tend to stabilize benzoic acids against decarboxylation, whereas para and ortho hydroxyls tend to destabilize them.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The colors of the powders of the four compounds are unusual: Fe(III) gallate is bluish black, as reported earlier, while the Mn(II) and Co(II) phases are medium brown and the Ni(II) phase is dark brown. We believe that the iron compound is more intensely colored than the other phases due to a strong ligand-to-metal charge transfer band from the phenolic oxygens. With the divalent cations, this band would be expected at higher energies in the ultraviolet region, overlapping less with the visible spectrum.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The colors of the powders of the four compounds are unusual: Fe(III) gallate is bluish black, as reported earlier, while the Mn(II) and Co(II) phases are medium brown and the Ni(II) phase is dark brown. We believe that the iron compound is more intensely colored than the other phases due to a strong ligand-to-metal charge transfer band from the phenolic oxygens. With the divalent cations, this band would be expected at higher energies in the ultraviolet region, overlapping less with the visible spectrum.

Analogous, but more linear, antiferromagnetic chains of <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-corner-sharing metal octahedra are found in Rb<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>FeF<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> and its hydrates. elements.clean_text: Magnetic susceptibility data were obtained for the powders of all four compounds. Zero-field-cooled data did not differ significantly from field-cooled data. From the slopes of the  1 / χ  plots ( ) in their high-temperature linear regimes, the magnetic moments per metal ion were found to be 5.69 BM for Mn(II) gallate, 6.49 BM for Fe(III) gallate, 4.89 BM for Co(II) gallate, and 3.22 BM for Ni(II) gallate, in reasonable agreement with expectations for these ions in octahedral coordination with oxygen. The Curie-Weiss temperatures, Θ, are -354.5 K for Fe(III) gallate, -29.5 K for Ni(II) gallate, -52.0 K for Co(II) gallate, and -41.5 K for Mn(II) gallate. We ascribe the higher value for the iron compound to the higher charge of Fe(III) compared with the M(II) phases. Co(II) and Ni(II) gallates exhibit peaks in susceptibility at 43 K and 19 K, respectively, indicating antiferromagnetic (AF) behavior below these temperatures. The high   T N   and strong AF ordering of the Co(II) phase suggest that its M O M angle may be at the high end of our estimated range, closer to linearity. Conversely, the absence of AF order for the Mn(II) phase may stem from its more acute M O M angle. Analogous, but more linear, antiferromagnetic chains of trans-corner-sharing metal octahedra are found in Rb2FeF5 and its hydrates. Studies of these compounds  reported antiferromagnetic behavior qualitatively similar to that of the Ni(II) and Co(II) gallates.

By contrast, we have used hydrothermal methods to synthesize the Fe(III), Mn(II), Co(II) and Ni(II) compounds. Bluish-black rod-shaped crystals (<mml:math altimg="si13.gif" overflow="scroll">

This mixture was sealed in a teflon-lined Parr acid digestion bomb and heated at 100 °C under autogenous pressure for 72 h. cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental details

Synthesis

Wunderlich et al. originally grew crystals of iron gallate at room temperature using the silica gel method . By contrast, we have used hydrothermal methods to synthesize the Fe(III), Mn(II), Co(II) and Ni(II) compounds. Bluish-black rod-shaped crystals ( 0.3 × 0.1 × 0.1   mm ) of Fe(III) gallate were synthesized by combining 1 mmol (199 mg) FeCl2⋅4H2O (Aldrich, 99%) and 1 mmol (188 mg) gallic acid monohydrate (Alfa Aesar, 98+%) with 10 mL of 0.05M KOH. This mixture was sealed in a teflon-lined Parr acid digestion bomb and heated at 100°C under autogenous pressure for 72 h. The reaction vessel was cooled at room temperature, and the product washed with deionized water and vacuum-filtered. Phase-pure powders were produced by combining 50 mg NaSO3 (Fisher, ACS grade) with the FeCl2⋅4H2O and gallic acid in 10 mL of 0.06 M KOH, and heating at 125°C under autogenous pressure for 48 h. Medium-brown rod-shaped crystals ( 0.5 × 0.1 × 0.1   mm ) of Mn(II) gallate were synthesized in a similar manner but using 1 mmol (169 mg) MnSO4⋅H2O (ACROS, 99%). This mixture was heated at 110°C for 67 h. A phase-pure powder was produced similarly, but using 0.1 M KOH instead of 0.06 M. A dark brown block-shaped crystal ( 0.07 × 0.1 × 0.1   mm ) of Ni(II) gallate was isolated from a phase-pure powder that had been prepared by heating 1 mmol (249 mg) Ni(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O (Aldrich, 98%) and 1 mmol gallic acid monohydrate in 10 mL deionized water at 100°C for 93 h. Larger block crystals were later grown using only 150 mg Ni(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O and heating at 110°C for 46 h, but these were not necessary for structure solution. No single crystals of Co(II) gallate were obtained, but phase-pure powders were made using 1 mmol (238 mg) CoCl2⋅6H2O (Aldrich, 98%) and 1 mmol gallic acid monohydrate in 10 mL of 0.04 M KOH, heated to 100°C for 48 h. Later, some microcrystals were grown using cobalt (II) acetate and acetylacetonate in deionized water, at  1 : 1  and  1 : 2  stoichiometries with the gallic acid, and at lower overall concentrations than before. Phase-pure powders with microcrystals were grown between 75-150°C.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

We report the synthesis, crystal structures, magnetic properties, and thermal behavior of a family of isostructural transition metal gallate dihydrates containing infinite chains of trans-corner-sharing  M  O 6   octahedra. The gallates crystallize in the enantiomorphic space groups  P  3 1  21  and  P  3 2  21 , chirality being imparted by helical motifs in the structure. Ni(C7O5H4)⋅2H2O:  a = 8.824 ( 2 )   Å ,  c = 10.644 ( 2 )   Å ; Mn(C7O5H4)⋅2H2O:  a = 9.063 ( 2 )   Å ,  c = 10.947 ( 2 )   Å ; Co(C7O5H4)⋅2H2O:  a = 8.910 ( 2 )   Å ,  c = 10.887 ( 2 )   Å . The Co(II) and Ni(II) gallates exhibit antiferromagnetic behavior, with   T N  = 43  and 19 K, respectively, while Mn(II) gallate is paramagnetic down to 5 K. High-temperature X-ray powder diffraction indicates that crystallinity is lost near 200°C in all of the compounds. Decarboxylation of the gallate moieties is believed to facilitate this thermal decomposition.

Thermogravimetric curves for the gallates showed similar weight losses, but in different temperature ranges. Fe(III) gallate had the earliest weight loss, losing 68.0% of its total weight, mostly between 250 and 320°C. Mn(II) gallate lost 70.3%, but more gradually, with the major loss between 310 and 380°C. Ni(II) gallate similarly lost 72.5%, mostly between 320 and 390°C. Co(II) gallate had the latest and most gradual weight loss, losing 69.4% of its total weight, with the major loss between 310 and 415°C. Theoretical weight losses accompanying decomposition to binary oxides of the same valence are 69.2% for Fe(III), 72.6% for Mn(II), 71.6% for Ni(II), and 71.5% for Co(II). The formation of Fe2O3, MnO, NiO, and CoO is confirmed by peaks that appear in the high-temperature X-ray powder diffraction patterns above the temperatures of final mass loss. Very slight weight gains in Mn(II) and Co(II) gallates in the highest temperature range (above 450°C) presumably correspond to further oxidation of MnO and CoO to Mn2O3 and Co3O4, respectively. High-temperature powder diffraction indicates that crystallinity is lost much earlier than the major TGA weight losses: below 150°C for Fe(III) gallate, around 200°C for Co(II) and Mn(II) gallate, and slightly above 200°C for Ni (II) gallate.

Magnetic susceptibility data were obtained for the powders of all four compounds. Zero-field-cooled data did not differ significantly from field-cooled data. From the slopes of the  1 / χ  plots ( ) in their high-temperature linear regimes, the magnetic moments per metal ion were found to be 5.69 BM for Mn(II) gallate, 6.49 BM for Fe(III) gallate, 4.89 BM for Co(II) gallate, and 3.22 BM for Ni(II) gallate, in reasonable agreement with expectations for these ions in octahedral coordination with oxygen. The Curie-Weiss temperatures, Θ, are -354.5 K for Fe(III) gallate, -29.5 K for Ni(II) gallate, -52.0 K for Co(II) gallate, and -41.5 K for Mn(II) gallate. We ascribe the higher value for the iron compound to the higher charge of Fe(III) compared with the M(II) phases. Co(II) and Ni(II) gallates exhibit peaks in susceptibility at 43 K and 19 K, respectively, indicating antiferromagnetic (AF) behavior below these temperatures. The high   T N   and strong AF ordering of the Co(II) phase suggest that its M O M angle may be at the high end of our estimated range, closer to linearity. Conversely, the absence of AF order for the Mn(II) phase may stem from its more acute M O M angle. Analogous, but more linear, antiferromagnetic chains of trans-corner-sharing metal octahedra are found in Rb2FeF5 and its hydrates. Studies of these compounds  reported antiferromagnetic behavior qualitatively similar to that of the Ni(II) and Co(II) gallates.
